content.webTitle: Football: Championship round-up: Bromwich stage late show

fields.headline: Three and easy: West Bromwich stage late show
fields.bodyText: Three goals in the last four minutes helped West Bromwich Albion to a flattering 4-0 win at home to Ipswich Town on Saturday. Andrade Filipe Teixeira and Kevin Phillips, with two, scored the late goals after Ishmael Miller had struck in the first half. "I was delighted that we dug in when our backs were to the wall for half an hour of that second half," West Bromwich's manager, Tony Mowbray, said. "There might have been spells last season when we would have caved in under those circumstances." The late developments left Ipswich's manager, Jim Magilton, frustrated. "We should not have been beaten by four but I can live with us playing in the manner we did in the second half," he said. James Beattie scored twice as Sheffield United came from behind to beat Wolves 3-1 at Bramall Lane. The former Everton striker equalised Stephen Elliott's opener and then scored a penalty with seven minutes left before Jon Stead wrapped up victory in injury time. Bryan Robson, United's manager, yesterday said he is hopeful of signing the former Internazionale midfielder Ze Maria who has been on trial. The 34-year-old won 43 caps for Brazil. United's opponents tomorrow, Blackpool, needed a 90th-minute equaliser from Andy Morrell to draw 2-2 at Burnley. Steve Jones and Ade Akinbiyi scored for Burnley, Wes Hoolihan hit Blackpool's first with a penalty. The former Nigeria international Jay-Jay Okocha made his debut for Hull City but it was David Livermore who scored in the 87th minute to earn a 1-1 draw after Rory Delap had given Stoke City the lead. Scunthorpe United dropped from the top four to 11th place after a 2-0 loss to Barnsley at Oakwell. Marcus Williams scored an own goal in the 45th minute and Kayode Odejayi added the second. Sheffield Wednesday continued their dreadful start as Paul Gallagher scored the only goal of the game to give Preston North End their first league win of the season. Wednesday have now lost five out of five. Sylvain Ebanks-Blake scored twice to put Plymouth Argyle 2-0 up against Cardiff City, but goals from Gavin Rae, and Steve Thompson, secured Cardiff a 2-2 draw. The Czech forward David Strihavka struck his first Norwich City goal as the Canaries won 1-0 at home to Crystal Palace, who face their former manager Iain Dowie's Coventry City tomorrow. Leyton Orient regained top spot in League One, after Tranmere Rovers overtook them on Friday, with a 1-0 win at Yeovil Town thanks to Adam Boyd's goal. Oldham Athletic failed to move above Leeds United at the bottom of the table, losing 1-0 to Southend United In League Two Paul Ince won the battle of the former England captains as his MK Dons beat Terry Butcher's Brentford 3-0 with two goals from Keith Andrews, and one from Jemal Johnson.
